d990258d-fbbc-4827-bd6f-111b389136b0.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
d990258d-fbbc-4827-bd6f-111b389136b0.chunk:
So as a final example of divide and conquer, we 
will look at a problem called quick select.
  So selection is the problem of 
finding a specific position in   a list. So in particular we want to find the 
kth largest value in a sequence of length n.   So

69d22fb9-a0fb-4725-b148-2bf0daa3af93.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
69d22fb9-a0fb-4725-b148-2bf0daa3af93.chunk:
of course one way to do this is to sort the 
list in descending order, and then the largest   value is the first one, the second largest value 
is the second one and so on, so by just looking at   position k in the sorted list in descending 
order we will

b3e40454-28a2-4f5e-afbc-a4b55e13b771.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
b3e40454-28a2-4f5e-afbc-a4b55e13b771.chunk:
get the kth largest value.
  So since we know we can sort in n log n, 
this would mean that the kth largest value,   the selection problem of finding the 
kth largest value also takes n log n.   But if we look at some special cases it perhaps 
suggests tha

33196039-6795-40d8-9770-447f7a590daa.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
33196039-6795-40d8-9770-447f7a590daa.chunk:
t we could do better. For instance,   if we want k equal to 1 then we are just 
looking for the largest value in the list   and that is just the maximum. And we know 
that we can compute the maximum in a list   in a single scan so it only takes order 
n ti

cc3be730-e987-459f-934e-47d84c11efe1.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
cc3be730-e987-459f-934e-47d84c11efe1.chunk:
me, it does not take n log n time.
  Similarly, if k is equal to n, that is, we want 
the smallest value in the list, then we can just   compute the minimum in a single scan of order 
n. So the question is can we do this for all k?   So if we fix a k, then

3556ab3c-25a0-4c5a-9410-a4c79cbba57f.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
3556ab3c-25a0-4c5a-9410-a4c79cbba57f.chunk:
of course in 
the first pass we can find the largest,   and then among the remaining in the second 
pass we can find the second largest. 
  So we can make k passes and in order k times n 
time, we can always find the kth largest. Now, the   problem is tha

2eb89024-baa7-4a59-84fa-3fd95e4f012d.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
2eb89024-baa7-4a59-84fa-3fd95e4f012d.chunk:
t as k becomes large, in particular, 
if k is like n minus 1 or n by 2 for instance,   then this would become order n squared.
So in particular the median is the value in   the center of the list so if we sort the list then 
the median will be the value at

ca669161-2a8b-4db6-a910-e7d558de8d87.chunk:
position n by 2.   So if we just use this naive thing here then 
the time it will take to find the median   is n by 2 passes on a list of length 
n which will be order n squared.
  Now remember that one thing we had said before is 
that if we can actually

2d15b4e3-6bf4-4aae-bb7f-a6b94619e6de.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
2d15b4e3-6bf4-4aae-bb7f-a6b94619e6de.chunk:
find the median quickly in   order n time, then what we can do is we can take 
this list and then find the median as the pivot   and then create this lower list and this upper 
list which are roughly half because the median   will divide it into two parts

3e22b43b-01d9-4fd2-a97c-2281584e5fe1.title: Divide and Conquer  Quick Select
3e22b43b-01d9-4fd2-a97c-2281584e5fe1.chunk:
which are half.
And if the two are half and we recursively sort   them then we will get a recurrence like merge 
sort. So quick sort will also become order n log   n. So that would be a side benefit of being able 
to do the selection problem in order n ti

me.

that is smaller

part before and the upper

particular segment, if
